questions.solution:
Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes consist of small lumina circumscribed by neoplastic cells joined at their apexes to produce a form of internal limiting (basement) membrane.

They are seen in:-

  • Retinoblastomas (choice A)
  • Pineoblastomas (choice B)
  • Medulloepitheliomas (choice C).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosette: This structure is characterized by tumor cells arranged in a radial, spoke-and-wheel pattern around a central lumen. The central space often contains cytoplasmic extensions from the surrounding cells, indicative of photoreceptor differentiation. The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is particularly characteristic of retinoblastoma, a malignant retinal tumor commonly affecting children. These rosettes can also be found in other neoplasms, such as pinealoblastomas and medulloepitheliomas.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of pilocytic astrocytomas?
questions.solution:
• The vessels in pilocytic astrocytomas can be markedly hyalinized (choice B), and vascular proliferation may be quite prominent (choice A).
  • The presence of necrosis in the absence of a history of prior radiation should make you consider an alternative diagnosis, but microvascular endothelial proliferation is allowed and quite common in pilocytic astrocytomas.
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies ( choice C) are a hallmark of slowly growing lesions and are a helpful feature along with Rosenthal fibers
  • These can be challenging to diagnose, but look for the aforementioned classic features of pilocytic astrocytomas ( especially eosinophilic granular bodies and Rosenthal fibers).
  • Mitotic figures are usually very difficult to find in pilocytic astrocytomas and are never brisk ( choice C).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pilocytic astrocytoma (PA) is a World Health Organization (WHO) grade I glioma, commonly seen in children and young adults. It is a slow-growing, often benign tumor originating from astrocytes, the supportive glial cells in the brain and spinal cord.

choices.text: It is the most common tumor to occupy the sella turcica in a child
It may be mistaken for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma
It is derived from Rathke pouch epithelium

questions.text: Which statement regarding the suprasellar tumor depicted below is FALSE?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a craniopharyngioma, papillary-variant, as evidenced by papillae lined by well-differentiated squamous epithelium lacking surface maturation.

  • All of the listed statements are true.
  • Craniopharyngiomas are the most common tumors to occupy the sella turcica in the pediatric population (choice A), while pituitary adenomas are more common in this location in adults.

Craniopharyngiomas are divided into two main histological subtypes:

  • Adamantinomatous Craniopharyngioma (common in children):
    • Features:
      • Stratified squamous epithelium.
      • Cysts filled with "motor oil-like" fluid (cholesterol-rich).
      • Calcifications (seen on imaging).
      • Wet keratin (eosinophilic debris).
    • Associated with CTNNB1 (beta-catenin) mutations.

  • Craniopharyngioma (common in adults):
    •  Features:
      • Well-differentiated squamous epithelium.
      • Lack of keratin or calcifications.
    • Associated with BRAF V600E mutations.
  • Due to the presence of squamous nests, this tumor can be mistaken for a metastatic squamous cell carcinoma (choice C), particularly in the adult population.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Craniopharyngioma is a benign, slow-growing epithelial tumor of the sellar and suprasellar region, arising from remnants of Rathke's pouch. It is classified as a WHO grade I tumor but can cause significant morbidity due to its proximity to critical structures.

choices.text: No extension into the depths of sulci
Lysis of clot occurs within a week

questions.solution:
• The dura is composed of two layers-an external collagenous layer and an inner more cellular layer containing fibroblasts.
  • Bridging veins travel from the convexities of the cerebral hemispheres through the subarachnoid space and dura to empty into the dural sinuses.
  • The brain is suspended in CSF, but the venous sinuses are fixed relative to the dura; as a result, traumatic displacement of the brain can tear the veins at the point where they penetrate the dura.
  • The extravasated blood dissects through the two layers of the dura, producing a subdural hematoma.
  • In older individuals with brain atrophy, the bridging veins are stretched, hence the increasing incidence of subdural hematoma with aging.
  • Infants are also very susceptible to subdural hematomas because their bridging veins are thin-walled.
  • Epidural hematoma:- most often occurs with temporal skull fractures in which the fracture crosses the course of the vessel.
  • Grossly:- collection of freshly clotted blood along the brain surface, without extension into the depths of sulci (choice C).
  • Usually, venous bleeding is self-limited (choice A) and the resulting hematoma is broken down and organized over time; sequence:
    • Lysis of the clot (about 1 week) (choice D)
    • Growth of fibroblasts from the dural surface into the hematoma (2 weeks)
    • Early development of hyalinized connective tissue (1 to 3 months)
  • Typically, the organized hematoma is firmly attached to the inner surface of the dura by ingrowing fibrous tissue, which does not contribute to healing. The lesion can eventually retract as the granulation tissue matures until only a thin layer of reactive connective tissue remains ("subdural membranes").
  • multiple recurrent episodes of bleeding occur (chronic subdural hematoma), presumably from the thin-walled vessels of the granulation tissue.
  • Clinical Features:- within 48 hours of injury.
    • Most common over the lateral aspects of the cerebral hemispheres and are bilateral in about 10% of cases.
    • Neurologic signs are attributable to the pressure exerted on the adjacent brain.
    • headache and confusion.
    • Slowly progressive neurologic deterioration

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The brain is suspended in CSF, but the venous sinuses are fixed relative to the dura; as a result, traumatic displacement of the brain can tear the veins at the point where they penetrate the dura.

The extravasated blood dissects through the two layers of the dura, producing a subdural hematoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common culprit of the embolism to the brain?
questions.solution:
Focal cerebral ischemia:-

  • Occlusive vascular disease of severity sufficient to lead to cerebral infarction may be due to
    • Embolization from a distant source
    • In situ thrombosis
    • Vasculitides
  • Embolism to the brain occurs from a variety of sources.
    • CARDIAC MURAL THROMBI are among the most common culprits
    • Predisposing factors:- myocardial infarct, valvular disease, and atrial fibrillation
    • Next in frequency are thromboemboli originating from arteries, most within the carotids.
    • Other sources of emboli include paradoxical thromboemboli, particularly in children with cardiac anomalies; thromboemboli associated with cardiac surgery; and emboli of other types (tumor, fat, or air). The territory supplied by the middle cerebral artery-the direct extension of the internal carotid artery-is most frequently affected by embolic infarction; the incidence is about equal in the two hemispheres.
    • Emboli tend to lodge where blood vessels branch or in areas of preexisting luminal stenosis.
    • "Shower embolization," as in fat embolism, may occur after fractures; affected individuals manifest generalized cerebral dysfunction with disturbances of higher cortical function and consciousness, often without localizing signs.
    • Widespread hemorrhagic lesions involving the white matter are characteristic of embolization of bone marrow after trauma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:A brain embolism caused by a cardiac mural thrombus occurs when a thrombus (blood clot) formed on the wall of the heart becomes dislodged and travels to the cerebral circulation, causing an ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).

choices.text: Most commonly involves putamen and globus pallidus

questions.text: All are true about lacunar infarct, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Hypertension affects the deep penetrating arteries and arterioles that supply the basal ganglia and hemispheric white matter as well as the brainstem; these cerebral vessels develop arteriolosclerosis(choice C), also known as small vessel disease because it affects arteries 40 to 900 µm in diameter.
  • If this disease process progresses to thrombosis and complete vessel occlusion, the end-result is development of small cavitary infarcts (choice D) known as lacunes or lacunar infarcts.
  • These lakelike spaces, defined as less than 15 mm wide, can be single or multiple and involve the putamen > globus pallidus > thalamus > internal capsule > deep white matter > caudate nucleus >
  • Microscopy:- Tissue loss surrounded by gliosis (choice B).

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Depending on their location in the CNS, lacunar infarcts can be clinically silent or cause severe neurologic impairment. Affected vessels may also be associated with widening of the perivascular spaces without tissue infarction.

choices.text: Pyramidal neurons in the cerebral cortex

questions.text: The most sensitive neurons in the brain during global cerebral hypoxia is:
questions.solution:
Global cerebral hypoxia or ischemia

  • occurs when there is a generalized reduction of cerebral perfusion (as in cardiac arrest, shock, and severe hypotension) or decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood (e.g., in carbon monoxide poisoning).
  • In mild cases, there may only be a transient postischemic confusional state, followed by complete recovery.
  • Irreversible CNS damage may occur in individuals who experience global hypoxic and/or ischemic insults (diffuse hypoxic/ischemic encephalopathy).
  • Among CNS cells, there is a hierarchy of sensitivity to hypoxia/ ischemia:
    • NEURONS > glial cells (oligodendrocytes and astrocytes) are also vulnerable.
    • The most sensitive neurons in the brain:-
      • Pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus (especially area CA1, also referred to as Sommer sector)
      • cerebellar Purkinje cells
      • pyramidal neurons in the cerebral cortex (especially layers III and V);
  • With severe global cerebral hypoxia/ ischemia, widespread neuronal death occurs, irrespective of regional vulnerability; patients who survive this injury often remain in a persistent vegetative state.
  • the current clinical criteria for "BRAIN DEATH":- evidence of irreversible diffuse cortical injury (isoelectric, or "flat," electroencephalogram), brainstem damage (such as absent reflexes and respiratory drive), and absent cerebral perfusion.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Global cerebral hypoxia or ischemia occurs when there is a generalized reduction of cerebral perfusion (as in cardiac arrest, shock, and severe hypotension) or decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood (e.g., in carbon monoxide poisoning).

choices.text: Damage to the sensory axons in the proximal roots

questions.solution:
NEUROSYPHILIS:-

  • Tabes dorsalis is the result of DAMAGE TO THE SENSORY AXONS IN THE DORSAL ROOTS.
  • Impaired joint position sense and ataxia (locomotor ataxia);
  • Loss of pain sensation, leading to skin and joint damage (Charcot joints); other
  • Sensory disturbances, particularly the characteristic "lightning pains"; and
  • Absence of deep tendon reflexes.
  • On microscopic examination - there is loss of both axons and myelin in the dorsal roots, with corresponding pallor and atrophy in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord. Organisms are not demonstrable in the cord lesions.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

questions.text: The following microscopic image of the viral encephalitis show which of the following feature?
questions.solution:
Arthropod-Borne Viral Encephalitis

  • Arboviruses à important cause of epidemic encephalitis
  • Characteristically, there is a meningoencephalitis marked by the PERIVASCULAR ACCUMULATION OF LYMPHOCYTES (and sometimes neutrophils)(shown in the image)
  • Multiple foci of necrosis of gray and white matter are found; in particular, there is evidence of single-cell neuronal necrosis with phagocytosis of the debris (neuronophagia).
  • Microglial cells form small aggregates, called microglial nodules
  • In severe cases, there may be a necrotizing vasculitis with associated focal hemorrhages.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Viral encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain parenchyma caused by viral infections.

Key Histological Features

  1. Perivascular Cuffing:
    • Lymphocytes, plasma cells, and monocytes accumulate around blood vessels in the brain parenchyma.
    • Reflects immune response to viral invasion.
  2. Neuronophagia:
    • Phagocytosis of infected and damaged neurons by activated microglia.
    • Common in severe cases, indicative of neuronal injury.
  3. Microglial Nodules:
    • Focal aggregates of activated microglial cells at sites of neuronal destruction.
    • A hallmark of viral encephalitis.

questions.text: An older age male patient having unilateral visual impairment, ataxia, nystagmus and lower limbs sensory and motor impairment. Patient has lost bladder control as well. CSF examination reveals mildly elevated protein level and moderate pleocytosis. IgG levels in the CSF were increased. MRI findings show plaque in lateral ventricle of the brain and in the spinal cord. Gross and microscopic images are given below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings, gross and microscopic images suggest the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is caused by an autoimmune response directed against components of the myelin sheath.

  • White matter disease
  • In the fresh state, the lesions are firmer than the surrounding white matter ("sclerosis") and appear as well circumscribed, somewhat depressed, glassy, gray-tan, irregularly shaped PLAQUES.
  • Plaques commonly occur adjacent to the lateral ventricles and are also frequent in the corpus callosum, optic nerves and chiasm, brainstem, ascending and descending fiber tracts, cerebellum, and spinal cord.
  • Plaques can extend into gray matter because myelinated fibers are present there as well.
  • Microscopically, in an active plaque, there is ongoing myelin breakdown associated with abundant FOAMY MACROPHAGES; (shown in the image) lymphocytes are also present, mostly as perivascular cuffs, especially at the outer edge of the lesion.
  • As lesions become quiescent, the inflammatory cells slowly disappear.
  • Within inactive plaques, there is no macrophage-rich infiltrate, little to no myelin is found, and there is a reduction in the number of oligodendrocyte nuclei; instead, reactive gliosis is prominent. Diminished axons.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by inflammation, demyelination, gliosis, and axonal damage.

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical marker is the most sensitive for the following benign dural tumor?
questions.solution:
Meningioma

  • Dural tumor, Benign, slow growing
  • Derived from meningothelial cells of arachnoid layer
  • General classic findings:-
    • Oval nuclei with delicate chromatin
    • Frequent intranuclear pseudoinclusions
    • Syncytial tumor cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm
    • Numerous whorls. Occasional psammoma bodies.
  • Risk increases with age. F>M
  • Grossly:- rubbery/firm
  • On imaging :- characteristic "dural tail"
  • IHC:- (+) Somatostatin receptor 2A (SSTR2A) is likely the most sensitive/specific.
    • Also, (+) EMA, Vimentin, PR.
    • (+/-) S100
    • Ki67 - varies With grade
  • Molecular:- NF2 mutations common
  • Higher grade = more likely to recur / progress.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: MENINGIOMA

Common Histopathological Findings

  1. Whorls:
    • Concentric arrangements of tumor cells, forming onion-like structures.
    • Characteristic of meningothelial differentiation.
  2. Psammoma Bodies:
    • Laminated, calcified structures.
    • Common in Grade I subtypes, especially psammomatous meningioma.
  3. Vascular Proliferation:
    • Prominent vascularity, especially in angiomatous meningiomas.
  4. Brain Invasion:
    • Seen in Grade II and Grade III meningiomas.
    • Indicates more aggressive behavior.

choices.text: Patients with rapidly progressive dementia, it spreads by forming bulky masses
Vasocentric growth pattern of tumor cells in virchow-robin space

questions.text: All are true about primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL), EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL)

  • Sixth or seventh decades of life
  • 5 to 2:1 male/female ratio
  • Associated with:- HIV-1 infection, inherited immunologic disorders, diseases prompting organ transplantation, and other conditions necessitating iatrogenic immunosuppression. (Choice A)
  • DISCOHESIVE CELLS WITH SCANT CYTOPLASM
  • FREQUENT PERIVASCULAR INFILTRATION
  • Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma of the CNS: DLBCL Confined to the CNS at presentation. Often older Patients with cognitive dysfunction and a single Supratentorial mass. Need tissue to Dx→ important to not give steroids before surgery as may cause tumor Waning making it harder to Dx.
    • Highly cellular, diffuse, patternless growth.
    • Often Necrosis with viable perivascular islands.
    • Perivascular Infiltration of nearby brain.
    • IHC: (+) PAX5, CD20, CD19. NOT virus related.
  • Immunodeficiency-associated CNS lymphomas: Most Common in AIDS. EBV-associated. Often multifocal.
  • Other Lymphomas: Lymphomatoid granulomatosis, Intravascular Large B cell lymphoma, Extranodal Marginal lymphoma of mucosa-associated lymphoid Tissue (MALT) lymphoma of the dura.
  • Rapidly progressing dementia has been associated with a distinctive subset of PCNSLs that diffusely permeate the brain rather than forming bulky masses ("lymphomatosis cerebri"). (Choice C)
  • A striking histologic feature of many PCNSLs is the tendency for tumor cells to aggregate in Virchow-Robin spaces and to infiltrate the walls of cerebral vessels. (Choice D)

questions.text: The following microscopic image is of a mass restricted to the cerebral hemisphere of an adult man. Ki67 index was high with TP53 gene mutation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
DIFFUSE ASTROCYTOMA :-

  • Also known as "Diffuse astrocytoma, IDH-mutant"
  • A diffusely infiltrating astrocytoma with a mutation in either the IDH1 or IDH2 gene (in adults).
  • NO CDKN2A/B homozygous deletions
  • Most common in young adults (mid-30s), most Commonly in frontal lobes (but can get anywhere in CNS). Commonly present with seizures.
  • Well-differentiated fibrillary astrocytes.
  • Cellularity is moderately increased.
  • Moderate nuclear atypia. Often loose microcystic background.
  • Mitotic activity is generally absent
  • Molecular/IHC: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations
  • Most common mutation (~90%) is IDH1 R132H → can detect with mutation-specific IHC
  • ATRX mutation → loss of ATRX IHC staining
  • TP53 mutation→ strong nuclear p53 IHC staining
  • Ki67 usually <4%. Express GFAP.
  • Slow growth.
  • Survival >5yrs (now often >10 yrs!).
  • Intrinsic capacity for malignant progression →Anaplastic astrocytoma → GBM.

Gemistocytic Astrocytoma: A variant of IDH-mutated astrocytoma with prominent gemistocytic neoplastic Astrocytes (>20%). Historically thought to progress Faster, but may not be true.

Contain a minor complement of large tumor cells characterized by eccentric globose "bellies" of glassy eosinophilic cytoplasm and peripherally displaced nuclei that seem on the verge of extrusion from their parent cell bodies.

Termed gemistocytes (from the Greek gemistos for laden or full), these reflect an accumulation of glial-type intermediate filaments (GFAPs) that form compacted paranuclear whorls and extend into stout cytoplasmic processes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: CNS lymphoma is a high-grade malignancy with characteristic periventricular lesions on imaging and angiocentric histology. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

choices.text: Coagulative necrosis lined by palisading tumor cells
Admixture of gliomatous and sarcomatous tissue
Uniform, round nuclei and clear perinuclear halos
Rosenthal fibres and eosinophilic granular bodies

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important microscopic feature of glioblastoma?
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV)

High-grade glioma with predominantly astrocytic differentiation with nuclear atypia, mitotic activity, AND microvascular proliferation, and/or necrosis.

  • Often diffuse growth.
  • Variable histology (hence "multiforme"): Highly cellular with poorly differentiated, sometimes Very pleomorphic tumor cells.
  • Brisk mitotic activity.
  • Either necrosis or microvascular proliferation. → glomeruloid tufts of multilayered mitotically Active endothelium with smooth muscle and Pericytes.
  • Often near necrosis.
  • Often regional heterogeneity.
  • Tumor cells will often migrate/invade around existing Structures, e.g., around neurons (satellitosis), in Subpial zone, etc..

KEY TAKEAWAYS: High-grade glioma with predominantly astrocytic differentiation with nuclear atypia, mitotic activity, AND microvascular proliferation, and/or necrosis.

questions.text: 9 years old male having an intracranial mass situated within the fourth ventricle and complains of seizures and focal motor deficits.
questions.solution:
Ependymoma (WHO grade II or III)

  • Circumscribed glioma
  • Composed of uniform small cells with round nuclei and speckled chromatin in a fibfrillary matrix
  • Characteristic pseudorosettes (perivascular anucleate zones) found in practically every case
  • TRUE ependymal rosettes (bland cuboidal cells arranged around a central lumen) found in ~1/3 of cases
  • Mainly intracranial, can get in spinal cord
  • Can occur in both children and adults
  • In children → usually posterior fossa (often 4th ventricle)
  • IHC :- (+) EMA, GFAP in pseudorosettes, S100
  • Morphological subtypes of ependymoma exist (tanycytic, clear cell, papillary), but do not impact prognosis.
  • Subependymoma and myxopapillary ependymoma are identified morphologically.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Ependymoma is Characterised by pseudorosettes (perivascular anucleate zones) found in practically every case
